title: Coffee Shop Profitability
candidate_prompt: BeanScene is a national coffee chain with 500 locations. Revenue is up 5% YoY, but profits are down 20%. The CEO wants to understand why and what to do.
case_objectives: Diagnose root cause of profit decline despite revenue growth

level_1.name: Fail
indicators: Jumps straight to generic solutions (cut costs, raise prices)
No breakdown of P&L or profit equation
Mentions vague factors like 'inflation' without analysis
level_1.example: Profits are down because costs are probably higher, like rent and wages. They should increase prices or cut staff.

level_2.name: Weak / Low Pass
indicators: Correctly notes costs must be the issue
Lists possible cost drivers but treats all equally
No hypothesis formed before asking for data
Asks for data but doesn't know what to do with it
level_2.example: Let me break this into revenue and costs. Revenue is up so it must be costs. Could be labour, rent, beans, utilities. Can I see the cost breakdown?

level_3.name: Good But Not Enough
indicators: Asks whether growth is price or volume led
Identifies primary cost drivers with data
level_3.example: Profit = Revenue - Costs. Revenue up 5% but profit down 20% suggests margin compression. I'd want to know if revenue growth is price or volume, and which costs increased most.

level_4.name: Clear Pass
indicators: Segments analysis (same-store vs new, fixed vs variable, product mix)
level_4.example: The objective is to restore profit sustainably. Revenue up but profit down sharply suggests margin erosion. I'd segment by same-store vs new-store, and fixed vs variable costs to isolate the driver.

level_5.name: Outstanding
indicators: Clear, logical framework for analyzing the problem
Strong hypothesis about margin pressure or cost drivers
Asks targeted, insightful questions to test hypotheses
Identifies key drivers with reasoning (e.g., labour costs, product mix)
level_5.example: Profit declining while revenue grows suggests margin compression. Let me structure this as revenue quality vs cost drivers. My hypothesis is variable costs are outpacing revenue growth - I'd want to see the cost breakdown by category.

store_performance.new_store_cannibalization: 15% of new stores cannibalizing existing locations
store_performance.store_level_variance: Top quartile 3x more profitable than average

margin_analysis.blended_margin_trend: Declining due to mix shift to food

hidden_facts.root_cause_summary: 80% of profit decline from labour inefficiency and low-margin product mix, not commodity costs

exploration_areas.description: How candidate frames and structures the problem
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Profit equation, hypothesis that costs are issue, segments for analysis
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: No structure, jumps to solutions, treats all factors equally

exploration_areas.description: Whether candidate forms hypotheses before diving into data
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Clear hypothesis about margin erosion, asks targeted questions
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Asks for all data without knowing what to test

exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Segments fixed/variable, identifies labour as key driver, quantifies impact
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Lists costs without prioritization, focuses on wrong drivers

exploration_areas.description: Understanding that revenue growth quality matters
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Asks if growth is price/volume led, identifies mix shift issue
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Assumes revenue is fine because it's growing

exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Prioritized by impact, specific actions, addresses risks
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Generic (cut costs, raise prices), no prioritization

exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Clear answer, quantified impact, action plan
